questions.text: A 40-year-old male was brought to ER after meeting with an accident and injured his perineum. He gets urge to micturate but not able to. O/E blood was seen at tip of urethra and swelling of penis and scrotum. Injury is?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Penile Urethra

 

Option A: Rupture of the penile/bulbar urethra leads to accumulation of urine in superficial perineal pouch, scrotum, around penis and can also extend to the lower anterior abdominal wall.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Prostatic urethra presents colliculus seminalis and receives the opening of ejaculatory duct, prostatic utricle and prostate glands. Prostatic urethra injuries are usually associated with pelvic fractures. The described scenario does not specifically indicate a pelvic fracture, and injuries to the prostatic urethra typically do not present with visible blood at the urethral meatus.

 

Option C. The membranous urethra is the most vulnerable part of the urethra to injury, particularly in the context of perineal trauma. It is the shortest and least dilatable part of the urethra and is located in the deep perineum. Given the mechanism of injury (perineal trauma) and the symptoms (inability to urinate, blood at the urethral meatus), an injury to the membranous urethra is highly plausible.

 

Option D. While a urinary bladder injury could lead to an inability to urinate and blood at the urethral meatus, such injuries are more commonly associated with pelvic fractures and blunt abdominal trauma. Additionally, bladder injuries often result in hematuria, but not necessarily visible blood at the urethral tip.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The penile urethra could be injured, especially considering the swelling of the penis and the presence of blood at the urethral meatus. However, penile urethral injuries are more commonly associated with direct trauma to the anterior part of the perineum or to the penis itself.

 

Ref: Vishram Singh Textbook of Anatomy 3rd Edition, Vol. II, Abdomen  Pg 238

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement about Levator Ani Muscle function and support:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Attached to Pelvic Brim.

 

Option D: Levator ani arises from the sides of the walls of the pelvis along the condensation of obturator fascia (the tendinous arch of levator ani).

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The levator ani muscle group plays a crucial role in supporting the pelvic viscera, including the bladder, intestines, and uterus in females. It forms a major part of the pelvic floor and helps maintain pelvic organ position and function. Levator ani supports pelvic viscera and counteracts downward thrust of diaphragm during increased intra-abdominal pressure.

 

Option B. The fibers of the levator ani muscles converge towards the midline and move downwards. This orientation is important for their role in supporting the pelvic organs and maintaining continence.

 

Option C. The levator ani muscle is comprised of a few parts, with the iliococcygeus and pubococcygeus being two of them. Levator ani and coccygeus together form pelvic diaphragm. The puborectalis is another component of this muscle group. Each part has a specific role in pelvic floor function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The levator ani muscles are not attached to the pelvic brim. Instead, they originate from the inner surface of the pelvis, specifically from the pelvic sidewalls and areas such as the pubis and ischial spine. The pelvic brim is the edge of the pelvic inlet, which is higher up and not the point of attachment for these muscles.

 

Ref: Vishram Singh, Textbook of Anatomy, 3rd Edition, Vol. II, Abdomen, Pg. 207

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a complaint of "feeling a bulge" in her vagina, which worsens by the end of the day or after prolonged standing. She also reports occasional urinary incontinence, especially when coughing or sneezing. On examination, there is evidence of a cystocele. The physician explains that her symptoms are due to pelvic floor weakness, which can affect various muscles and structures in the region. In the context of pelvic floor anatomy, which of the following muscles is NOT directly attached to the perineal body, and thus less likely to be involved in her condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ischiocavernosus

 

Option A:

 

  • The perineal body is a fibromuscular mass located in the center of the perineum, playing a crucial role in the integrity of the pelvic floor and supporting pelvic organs.

 

 

  • It serves as an attachment point for various muscles, including the bulbospongiosus, superficial transverse perinei, and deep transverse perinei, which all contribute to pelvic floor support.
  • The ischiocavernosus muscle, however, is primarily involved in erectile function and does not attach to the perineal body. It lies superficial to the perineal body and is not directly involved in supporting the pelvic organs, hence less relevant to the patient's symptoms of pelvic organ prolapse and stress urinary.
  • Ischiocavernosus arises from inner surface of ischio-pubic ramus and inserts into sides and undersurface of crus penis, compresses cavernous spaces of crus, impedes venous return and maintain erection of penis or clitoris.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Bulbospongiosus muscle is attached to the perineal body. In males, it covers the bulb of the penis and in females, the vestibular bulb. It contributes to the erection of the penis and clitoris, respectively, and also plays a role in ejaculation in males and in the closing of the vaginal orifice in females.

 

Option C. Superficial Transverse Perinei muscle also attaches to the perineal body. It is a small, superficial muscle in the perineal region that helps stabilize the perineal body.

 

Option D. The deep transverse perineal muscle, part of the urogenital diaphragm, is attached to the perineal body. It supports the pelvic floor and helps in maintaining continence of urine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ischiocavernosus muscle is not attached to the perineal body. Instead, it arises from the ischial tuberosity and the ischial ramus and extends along the sides of the penis in males and the clitoris in females. Its function is to help maintain erection by compressing the outflow of blood from the corpus cavernosum.

 

10 Muscles attached to perineal body

 

  • Levator Ani Muscle (2)
  • Superficial Tansverse Perineii (2)
  • Deep Transverse Perinei (2)
  • Bulbospongiosus (2)
  • Sphincter Urethrae (1)
  • External Anal Sphincter (1)

 

Ref: Vishram Singh Textbook of Anatomy 3rd Edition, Vol. II, Abdomen Pg 219

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents to the clinic complaining of discharge from his urethra. He denies any pain during urination or history of sexually transmitted infections. He mentions a recent episode of significant straining during bowel movements. Physical examination reveals no abnormalities of the external genitalia. A urethral swab is negative for gonococcal and chlamydial infection. The discharge is most likely originating from glands that open into which part of the urethra?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Spongy Urethra

 

Option B:

 

  • The bulbourethral glands, also known as Cowper's glands, open into the spongy urethra.
  • They are responsible for secreting a clear fluid that lubricates the urethra for sperm passage.
  • In the absence of infection or significant other symptoms, the discharge in this patient is likely to be related to the bulbourethral glands, which could be stimulated by straining or other physical factors.
  • The location of these glands and their association with the spongy urethra explains the nature and origin of the discharge.
  • Bulbourethral glands/Cowper’s glands are situated in deep perineal pouch on each side of membranous urethra. It’s duct pierce perineal membrane to open into intrabulbar fossa of spongy urethra

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The membranous urethra is a short segment of the male urethra that passes through the urogenital diaphragm. The bulbourethral glands do not open into this part of the urethra.

 

Option C. Prostatic Urethra runs through the prostate gland. The prostatic urethra receives the ejaculatory ducts and several prostatic ducts but not the ducts from the bulbourethral glands.

 

Option D. The term "intramural urethra" is not commonly used in anatomical terminology. The urethra is usually divided into the prostatic, membranous, and spongy (or penile) segments. The intramural urethra could refer to the part of the urethra that is embedded in the bladder wall, but this is not where the bulbourethral glands open.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The bulbourethral glands are located in the deep perineal pouch. They open into the spongy urethra, which is the longest part of the urethra and runs along the length of the penis. The secretions of these glands are responsible for lubricating the urethra and are released during sexual arousal, contributing to the pre-ejaculate fluid.

 

Ref: Vishram Singh Textbook of Anatomy 3rd Edition, Vol. II, Abdomen Pg 238

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient presents with lower urinary tract symptoms, including difficulty in starting and stopping urination, weak urinary stream, and a feeling of incomplete emptying of the bladder. During the digital rectal examination (DRE), the physician notes an enlargement of the prostate gland. The patient's symptoms are suggestive of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH). Which specific part of the prostate, known as the "uvula vesicae," is most likely responsible for causing these urinary symptoms in the patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Median Lobe

 

Option D:

 

  • Median lobe of prostate, its base forms uvula vesicae and is fibromuscular. Benign hypertrophy of prostate affects this lobe.
  • In cases of Benign Prostatic Hyperplasia (BPH), the median lobe of the prostate, also referred to as the "uvula vesicae," can become enlarged and protrude into the bladder.

 

 

  • This enlargement can obstruct the flow of urine through the urethra, leading to urinary symptoms such as weak stream, hesitancy, and incomplete emptying.
  • The enlargement of the anterior lobe, posterior lobe, or lateral lobes of the prostate is less likely to cause these specific urinary symptoms associated with BPH.
  • Understanding the specific anatomical involvement of the prostate can aid in diagnosing and managing the patient's clinical symptoms.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The anterior lobe of the prostate is less glandular and more fibromuscular. Anterior lobe is formed by the isthmus that connects the lateral lobe of both sides and is devoid of gland.  It's situated at the front of the prostate and does not have a significant impact on the uvula vesicae, which is a feature seen at the base of the bladder.

 

Option B. The posterior lobe is situated at the back of the prostate and is often the site of prostatic cancers. It is not directly involved in the formation of the uvula vesicae. Posterior lobe -lateral lobe continues behind urethra as posterior lobe and below ejaculatory duct.

 

Option C. Lateral Lobes are on either side of the prostate and are the most prominent parts of the gland. While they are significant in terms of size and are often the site of Benign Prostatic Hyperplasia (BPH), they do not contribute directly to the formation of the uvula vesicae.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The median lobe of the prostate is situated between the two lateral lobes and beneath the bladder neck. When enlarged, it can protrude into the bladder, leading to a noticeable bulge known as the uvula vesicae. This protrusion can be significant in conditions like BPH, where the median lobe's enlargement pushes upwards into the bladder base.

 

Ref: Vishram Singh Textbook of Anatomy 3rd Edition, Vol. II, Abdomen Pg 247

choices.text: It is not done to prevent Overstretching and Rupture of the Perineal Muscles and Fascia.
Posterolateral Episiotomy prevents Injury to the Rectus.

questions.text: While during her night duty in the labour ward, the newly joined intern was all excited to conduct her first normal delivery of a 22-year-old primigravida. The patient was close to term and had been admitted with complaints of severe pain in the lower abdomen radiating to back and thigh. The normal delivery was conducted by the duty PG in the labour ward. As the pain progressed and the baby was about to be delivered the PG instructed and assisted the newly joined intern to make a cut in the perineum following which the baby was delivered without much struggle and then the cut edges were approximated by sutures. Which of the following is true about the procedure performed by the intern?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) It is called Episiotomy.

 

Option A: Episiotomy is a surgically planned incision on the perineum and the posterior vaginal wall during the second stage of labour. Structures cut include skin, subcutaneous tissue, transverse perineal branches of pudendal vessels and nerves. Fascia covering perineal muscles, superficial and deep transverse perinei muscles, bulbospongiosus and part of levator ani, posterior vaginal wall.

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. It is wrong statement. An episiotomy is often performed to prevent severe tearing of the perineal muscles and fascia that might occur during childbirth. By controlling the site and extent of the incision, an episiotomy aims to reduce the risk of extensive perineal trauma.

 

Option C. It is wrong statement. In an episiotomy, the incision is made in the perineum, not the anterior vaginal wall. The cut usually extends from the vaginal opening towards the anus but does not involve the anterior vaginal wall.

 

Option D. This statement is also wrong.  Mediolateral episiotomy is done, where the cut is made diagonally away from the anus, can reduce the risk of injury to the anal sphincter and rectum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • This statement is true.

  • An episiotomy is a surgical cut made in the perineum — the area between the vagina and the anus — to enlarge the vaginal opening during childbirth. This procedure is performed to facilitate the delivery of the baby.

 

Ref: Gray’s Anatomy 41st Edition, Pg No. 1231

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with complaints of pain and swelling in the genital area following a trauma. The patient reports difficulty with urination and discomfort in the penile region. During the physical examination, the physician identifies a hematoma and suspects injury to the dorsal artery of the penis. In which anatomical layer does the dorsal artery of the penis pass beneath, and its injury can lead to these clinical symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Buck’s Fascia

 

Option B:

 

  • The Dorsal Artery of the penis passes beneath Buck’s fascia, which is a deep fascial layer within the male genital region.

  • Injury to this artery within Buck’s fascia can lead to the formation of a hematoma, causing pain, swelling, and discomfort in the penile area.

  • Additionally, injury to this artery may result in impaired blood flow to the penis, leading to difficulties with urination and potential erectile dysfunction.

  • Therefore, understanding the anatomical layers and structures in the male genital region is crucial for diagnosing and managing such clinical symptoms.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Deep fascia of perineum is colle’s fascia it fuses with the posterior part of urogenital diaphragm. This is a layer of superficial fascia found in the perineum. It is continuous with Scarpa's fascia in the abdomen and does not play a direct role in the penile structure. Therefore, it's not the layer beneath which the dorsal artery of the penis passes.

 

Option C. The dartos layer is a layer of smooth muscle fibers found within the scrotum, not the penis. It is responsible for the wrinkling of the scrotal skin and does not encompass the penile structure where the dorsal artery is located.

 

Option D. Tunica Albuginea is a fibrous envelope of the corpora cavernosa and is found deep to Buck’s fascia. While it is an important structural component of the penis, the dorsal artery of the penis does not pass beneath it but rather beneath Buck’s fascia.

 

Educational objective:

 

Buck's fascia is a deep fascia layer that encloses the corpora cavernosa penis. It is an important anatomical structure in the penis, providing a protective layer for the dorsal nerves, arteries, and veins of the penis. The dorsal artery of the penis travels just beneath this layer, making it crucial for its protection and functional integrity.

 

Ref: Vishram Singh Textbook of Anatomy 3rd Edition, Vol. II, Abdomen Pg 56

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman pregnant with her first child had been in the second stage of labor (pushing) for several hours. The crown of the child’s head was just visible through the vaginal orifice, but the obstetrician was concerned that the woman was exhausted and was no longer able to push effectively. She decided to perform an episiotomy to enlarge the opening of the birth canal and assist the delivery of the baby. If a midline episiotomy incision were to continue tearing, all the following structures could be damaged except?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Urethra

 

Option C: Urethra forms the anterior relation and is infrequently involved.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The perineal body is a fibromuscular mass located between the vaginal orifice and the anus. It is an important structure for the integrity of the perineum and is at risk of damage if a midline episiotomy extends. Damage to the perineal body can lead to weakness of the pelvic floor and associated complications. If the incision tears further during the delivery, a median incision is more likely than a posterolateral incision to extend posteriorly through the perineal body, the external anal sphincter, the internal anal sphincter, and the rectum.

 

 

Option B. In cases where a midline episiotomy extends or tears further, it can potentially involve the anterior wall of the rectum. This is particularly concerning as it can lead to complications like rectovaginal fistula. Serious tears may become infected by bowel contents, as may the child as it passes through the birth canal. This may delay or impair adequate healing for the mother or even present significant health risks (i.e. septicemia) for mother or child.

 

Option D. The external anal sphincter is at risk of damage if a midline episiotomy tears further. This can lead to issues with fecal incontinence if the sphincter is significantly damaged. External anal sphincter forms the posterior relation of vagina, if torn in episiotomy can later lead to faecal incontinence. The integrity of the perineal body is critical to the strength of the entire perineum in women. Unrepaired injury can cause dysfunction of the external anal sphincter, internal anal sphincter, and/or sexual dysfunction (e.g., dyspareunia).

 

Educational Objective:

 

The urethra, located anteriorly to the vaginal orifice, is generally not at risk of damage from a midline episiotomy. Midline episiotomies are made posteriorly and are aimed towards the perineum and anus. Therefore, the urethra is typically safe from damage in this scenario.

 

Ref: Vishram Singh, Textbook of Anatomy, 3rd Edition, Vol. II, Abdomen, Pg. 225

questions.text: A 72-year-old male presents with nocturia, difficulty initiating urination, and a sensation of incomplete bladder emptying. He has a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Digital rectal examination reveals an enlarged, firm, and smooth prostate. These symptoms are most likely due to the obstruction of the urinary tract caused by the enlargement of which part of the prostate gland?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Median Lobe

 

Option C:

 

  • Median lobe of prostate forms uvula vesicae at apex of trigonum of bladder and its enlargement results in BPH. Prostate is a fibromuscular gland and corresponds to paraurethral glands of skene in female in its development.

 

 

  • Prostate is traversed by ejaculatory duct, prostatic urethra, prostatic utricle.
  • Benign Prostatic Hyperplasia (BPH) primarily involves the periurethral and median lobes of the prostate gland.
  • The enlargement of the median lobe is particularly significant in causing urinary tract obstruction, as it can protrude into the bladder base and impinge on the urethral orifice, leading to symptoms such as difficulty initiating urination, nocturia, and a sensation of incomplete bladder emptying.
  • The lateral and posterior lobes can also enlarge in BPH, but the median lobe's enlargement is more directly associated with the obstructive symptoms due to its anatomical position relative to the urethra and bladder.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. While BPH can affect the entire Prostate gland, it typically does not involve uniform enlargement of all parts of the prostate. The enlargement is usually more pronounced in specific lobes.

 

Option B. The lateral lobes are often involved in BPH, and their enlargement can contribute to urinary obstruction. However, the characteristic feature that leads to the most significant urinary symptoms is the enlargement of another lobe.

 

 

Option D. The posterior lobe is more commonly associated with prostate cancer rather than BPH. Enlargement of the posterior lobe is not typically the main contributor to urinary obstruction in BPH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The enlargement of the median lobe of the prostate is most commonly associated with the obstruction seen in BPH. The median lobe, when enlarged, protrudes into the bladder and can impinge on the urethra, leading to urinary obstruction. This lobe's enlargement can cause a more significant impact on urinary flow than enlargement of other lobes.

 

Ref: Vishram Singh Textbook of Anatomy 3rd Edition, Vol. II, Abdomen Pg 243

questions.text: A 28-year-old male patient presents with a complaint of testicular pain and swelling following trauma to the groin area. During the physical examination, the physician tests the cremasteric reflex to assess the integrity of the nervous system. Which root value is primarily responsible for the cremasteric reflex, and its assessment can aid in diagnosing the patient's clinical symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) L1, L2

 

Option A: The correct root value for the cremasteric reflex is indeed L1, L2.

 

 

  • The cremasteric reflex is a reflexive contraction of the cremaster muscle that causes the testicle to be pulled upward in response to stroking the inner thigh.
  • This reflex is primarily mediated by the L1 and L2 spinal nerve roots.
  • Assessment of the cremasteric reflex is valuable in diagnosing conditions such as testicular torsion or other disorders causing testicular pain and swelling.
  • A brisk cremasteric reflex suggests an intact neural pathway, while its absence can indicate neurological issues or certain pathological conditions in the groin area.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. S2, S3 sacral nerve roots are more involved in the pelvic splanchnic nerves and contribute to the parasympathetic innervation of the pelvic organs. They are not involved in the cremasteric reflex.

 

Option C. L3, L4 lumbar nerve roots contribute to the femoral nerve and other structures, but they are not involved in the cremasteric reflex. The L3 and L4 nerve roots play a role in the patellar (knee-jerk) reflex, not the cremasteric reflex.

 

Option D. The L4 and S1 nerve roots are involved in the innervation of the lower limb, particularly in the sciatic nerve. They play a crucial role in reflexes like the ankle jerk reflex, but not in the cremasteric reflex.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cremasteric reflex involves the muscle that pulls up the testis (the cremaster muscle). This reflex is mediated by the fibers originating from the L1 and L2 spinal nerve roots. When the inner thigh is stroked, the sensory nerves (genitofemoral nerve, derived from L1 and L2) carry the stimulus to the spinal cord. The response is the contraction of the cremaster muscle, causing the elevation of the testis, and this motor response is also mediated by the genitofemoral nerve, originating from the L1 and L2 spinal segments.

 

 

Cremasteric reflex is absent in Torsion Testis

In UMN Lesions above segment L1, the Reflex is Lost

 

Ref: Vishram Singh Textbook of Anatomy 3rd Edition, Vol. II, Abdomen Pg 34

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents to the clinic with difficulty urinating and a weak urinary stream. He has a history of benign prostatic hyperplasia. On examination, there is tenderness in the perineal region. Digital rectal examination reveals an enlarged, non-tender prostate. His symptoms are most likely related to pathology in which part of the urethra?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Membranous Urethra

 

Option B:

 

  • The shortest part of the male urethra is indeed the membranous urethra.
  • The membranous urethra is the shortest and the least dilatable part of the male urethra.
  • It is particularly susceptible to injury due to its fixed position and the lack of surrounding spongy tissue.
  • In this patient, the perineal tenderness and difficulty in urination suggest involvement of the membranous urethra.
  • Benign prostatic hyperplasia primarily affects the prostatic urethra, but the patient's specific symptoms and the perineal tenderness point more towards a membranous urethra issue.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Prostatic Urethra runs through the prostate gland and is relatively longer than the membranous urethra. It is the widest and most dilatable part of the urethra, but not the shortest.

 

 

 

Option C. Bulbar Urethra is part of the spongy urethra that lies within the bulb of the penis. It is longer than the membranous urethra and extends up to the penile portion of the urethra.

 

Option D. Penile Urethra (also known as Spongy or Cavernous Urethra) is the longest part of the urethra, running the length of the penis. It extends from the end of the bulbar urethra to the external urethral orifice at the tip of the penis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The membranous urethra is the shortest segment of the male urethra. It passes through the urogenital diaphragm and is surrounded by the external urethral sphincter. It's typically about 1-2 cm long, making it the shortest part of the urethra.

 

 

Ref. Vishram Singh Textbook of Anatomy 3rd Edition, Vol. II, Abdomen Pg238

questions.text: Secondary support of the Uterus is?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Broad Ligament

 

Option D: The support of the uterus is typically divided into primary and secondary supports. Broad ligament is a broad fold of peritoneum that consists of two layers and extends from the lateral border of the uterus to the lateral pelvic wall.

 

Primary supports are the true ligaments and secondary supports are the folds of peritoneum which help in keeping the uterus in place.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Mackenrodt Ligament, Also known as the cardinal ligament, is a primary support of the uterus. It extends from the cervix to the lateral walls of the pelvis and is one of the key structures in maintaining the position of the uterus.

 

Option B. The uterosacral ligament is also considered a primary support of the uterus. It extends from the cervix to the sacrum and helps to maintain the uterus in its normal anteverted position.

 

Option C. The round ligament of the uterus runs from the uterine horns through the inguinal canal to the labia majora. It is considered a secondary support of the uterus. The round ligament plays a role in maintaining the anteverted position of the uterus but is not as significant in terms of overall support as the primary ligaments like the cardinal or uterosacral ligaments.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The broad ligament is a double layer of peritoneum that extends from the sides of the uterus to the lateral walls and floor of the pelvis. It encloses the fallopian tubes, ovaries, and related structures. While the broad ligament is associated with the uterus, it is not considered a significant structural support. since it is fold of peritoneum and not a true ligament. It is more of a mesentery that provides a pathway for blood vessels and nerves to the uterus and other pelvic structures.

 

Ref: Vishram Singh Textbook of Anatomy 3rd Edition, Vol. II, Abdomen, Pg. 273

choices.text: Abnormal Collection of Serous Fluid in a part of Tunica Vaginalis
Scrotal Injury could be a cause for development of Hydrocele in Later Life.
Testis and Spermatic Cord cannot be palpated separately.
Dartos Muscle is supplied by Genital Branch of Genitofemoral Nerve.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy was brought to the surgery OPD because of swelling over right scrotum. On examination, transillumination revealed fluid accumulation within the scrotum. This boy was diagnosed with hydrocele and was posted for surgery the next day. Which of the following statements is NOT true about hydrocele?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Dartos Muscle is supplied by Genital Branch of Genitofemoral Nerve.

 

Option D:

 

  • The dartos muscle is innervated by sympathetic fibers from the genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve (L1, L2).
  • The dartos muscle corrugates the scrotal skin, which is important for thermoregulation of the testes.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. A hydrocele is characterized by the accumulation of fluid in the tunica vaginalis, a pouch of serous membrane that covers the testes. This can lead to swelling in the scrotum, as seen in the patient.

 

Option B. Hydrocele can be caused by scrotal injury, inflammation, or other underlying conditions affecting the scrotum. It can develop immediately after the injury or later in life as a result of scarring or blockage in the drainage of fluid.

 

Option C. In most cases of hydrocele, the testis and the spermatic cord can still be palpated separately from the fluid collection. This is an important clinical sign in distinguishing hydrocele from other scrotal swellings, such as a hernia.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The dartos muscle, a layer of smooth muscle in the subcutaneous tissue of the scrotum, is actually innervated by sympathetic fibers from the genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve.

 

Ref: Gray’s Anatomy 41st edition, pg no. 1286

choices.text: Lymphatics from Scrotum Drain into Internal Iliac Nodes
Anterior Third of the Scrotum is supplied by Ilioinguinal and Genitofemoral Nerves
Layers of the Scrotum from Outer to Inner are Skin, Dartos, External Spermatic Fascia, Internal Spermatic Fascia, Cremaster, Parietal Layer of Tunica Vaginalis
Right Half of the Scrotum is lower than the Left Side

questions.text: A 30-year-old male was brought to ER with complaints of right sided scrotal pain and swelling that gradually worsened over the past 5 days. He complained of raised body temperature and chills. On examination, his right hemiscrotum is warm, tender and erythematous. Cremasteric Reflex is present. Scrotal ultrasound confirmed the diagnosis of scrotal abscess. Which of the following statements pertaining to the above case is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Anterior Third of the Scrotum is supplied by Ilioinguinal and Genitofemoral Nerves

 

Option B:

 

 

 

  • Anterior third of the scrotum is supplied by ilioinguinal and genitofemoral nerves
  • Posterior two third is supplied by scrotal branches of pudendal nerve.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The lymphatic drainage of the scrotum is primarily to the superficial inguinal lymph nodes, not the internal iliac nodes. The internal iliac nodes are involved in the lymphatic drainage of the deeper structures of the pelvis.

 

Option C. The correct order of scrotal layers from outer to inner is: Skin, Dartos Muscle and Fascia, External Spermatic Fascia, Cremasteric Muscle and Fascia, Internal Spermatic Fascia, and finally the Parietal Layer of the Tunica Vaginalis. The order presented in this option is mixed up.

 

Option D. While there can be individual variations in the level of the testicles, with one testicle often hanging slightly lower than the other, it is mostly seen that the right half of the scrotum is always lower than the left.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The anterior part of the scrotum is innervated by the ilioinguinal nerve (a branch of the first lumbar nerve) and the genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve (which originates from the lumbar plexus).
  • This innervation is important for sensory perception in the scrotal area.

 

Ref: Gray’s Anatomy 41st edition, pg no. 1286

choices.text: Blood Supply above Pectinate Line is through Superior Rectal Artery.
Lymphatic Drainage above Pectinate Line is through Superficial Inguinal Nodes.
Part above Pectinate Line develops from Proctodeum
Part above Pectinate line is supplied by Somatic Nerves.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents to the clinic with rectal bleeding. During the examination and history-taking, the physician explains to the medical student the importance of understanding the anatomy of the rectum, particularly the pectinate line, for diagnosing conditions like hemorrhoids and rectal cancer. Which of the following statements is true regarding the pectinate line?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Blood Supply above Pectinate Line is through Superior Rectal Artery.

 

Option A:

 

 

 

  • The pectinate line, also known as the dentate line, is an important anatomical boundary in the anal canal that separates two different regions with distinct embryological origins and characteristics.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. This statement is incorrect. Lymphatic drainage from the region above the pectinate line typically drains to the internal illiac lymph nodes. This is in contrast to the region below the pectinate line, which drains to the superficial inguinal lymph nodes.

 

Option C. This statement is incorrect. The part above the pectinate line, known as the "hindgut-derived" part of the anal canal, develops from the endodermal cloaca during embryogenesis. It is not derived from the proctodeum.

 

Option D. This statement is incorrect. The part above the pectinate line, also known as the "visceral" or "autonomic" part, is supplied by visceral nerves, which are part of the autonomic nervous system. It is insensitive to pain and temperature. In contrast, the part below the pectinate line is supplied by somatic nerves and is sensitive to pain and temperature.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Above the pectinate line, the blood supply to the anal canal is primarily through the superior rectal artery is the continuation of the inferior mesenteric artery. This arterial supply is part of the systemic circulation.

choices.text: The patient’s Urethra had been injured inside the Perineum because of the Fall Sustained.
The patient’s fall ruptured the Penile Urethra.
The Urine passed upward beneath the Membranous Layer of Superficial Fascia on the Anterior Abdominal Wall.
The Urine could not extend posteriorly because of the attachment of Colles’ Fascia to the Anococcygeal Raphe.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male, construction workercarrying a load on his head lost his balance and fell astride a rafter on the floor below. Immediately, he was taken to a nearby hospital. The medical practitioner on examination of the patient found that there was extensive swelling of the perineum, scrotum and penis. The lower part of his anterior abdominal wall was also swollen. The patient complained that he was not able to pass his urine normally and was passing only a few drops of blood-stained urine. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the above scenario?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) The Urine could not extend posteriorly because of the attachment of Colles’ Fascia to the Anococcygeal Raphe.

 

Option D: In the described scenario, the patient has suffered a traumatic injury likely affecting the urethra, leading to urinary retention and hematoma formation in the perineum, scrotum, and anterior abdominal wall.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. This statement is likely true. A fall astride with such a mechanism of injury commonly results in a straddle injury, which can cause trauma to the urethra, especially the bulbous and membranous parts that are located in the perineum.

 

Option B. The mechanism of injury described could lead to a rupture of the penile urethra. The swelling of the scrotum and penis suggests involvement of the spongy (penile) urethra.

 

 

Option C. This statement is true. In the case of urethral injury, urine can extravasate and track along fascial planes. Due to the attachments of Colles’ fascia in the perineum, urine can pass upward beneath the membranous layer of the superficial fascia (Scarpa's fascia) on the anterior abdominal wall, leading to swelling in this area.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In reality, Colles' fascia in the perineum is attached laterally to the ischiopubic rami and posteriorly to the perineal body, but it does not attach to the anococcygeal raphe. Therefore, in the case of a urethral rupture, urine and blood can indeed extend into the superficial perineal space but are prevented from extending into the thigh or posteriorly into the anal region due to these attachments.
  • Scarpa’s fascia of anterior abdominal wall when traced below it is continuous with the:
    • Fundiform Ligament of Penis
    • Dartos Muscle of the Scrotum
    • Colles Fascia of Perineum

 

Over the inguinal ligament, it blends with the fascia lata of the thigh along Holden’s line (extends laterally from pubic tubercle above the saphenous opening of the thigh).

 

Injury to the male (bulbar) urethra inside the perineum due to trauma will result in the extravasation of urine from superficial perineal pouch to the scrotum, penis and lower anterior abdominal wall, but not into the thigh because of attachment to Holden’s line. The urine could not extend posteriorly because of the attachment of the Colles’ fascia to the posterior edge of the perineal membrane.

 

Ref: Gray’s Anatomy 41st Edition, Pg No. 1069

choices.text: Round Ligament is attached to the Uerine Cornua below and in front of the Fallopian Tube
Anteversion is maintained by Cardinal Ligaments
Broad Ligament of Uterus is a False Ligament
Pubocervical Ligament is true Ligament of Uterus

questions.text: A 56-year-old female (post-menopausal) who had five children from normal delivery had been assisting the chief cook in a restaurant. For the past 6 months, she felt the sensation of something coming down the vagina. She fixed an appointment with a gynaecologist. She told the gynaecologist that she also had dribbling of urine while bending down and frequency of micturition. The gynaecologist performed a per vaginal examination which revealed the descent of the cervix into the vagina. Which of the following statements is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Anteversion is maintained by Cardinal Ligaments

 

Option B: In the context of the described case of a 56-year-old female with symptoms suggesting pelvic organ prolapsed.

 

 

Anteversion and anteflexion are terms used to describe the normal positioning of the uterus within the pelvis.

 

  • Anteversion: This term refers to the orientation of the uterus where it is tilted forward towards the bladder. In anteversion, the angle between the cervix and the vagina is such that the uterine body leans forward over the bladder, which is considered the normal position for the majority of women.
  • Anteflexion: describes the position where the body of the uterus is bent forward at the junction with the cervix. It is a forward bending of the uterus within itself, so that the body of the uterus forms an angle with the cervix. This is also considered a normal variation of uterine positioning.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The round ligaments of the uterus are fibromuscular structures that extend from the uterine cornua, pass through the inguinal canal, and terminate in the labia majora. They are located below and in front of the fallopian tubes and play a role in maintaining the anteversion of the uterus.

 

 

Option C. This statement is correct but needs clarification. The broad ligament is often referred to as a "false ligament" because it does not provide significant support to the uterus. It is more accurately described as a double layer of peritoneum that extends from the sides of the uterus to the lateral walls of the pelvis, enclosing the fallopian tubes, ovaries, and related structures.

 

 

Option D. This statement is correct. The pubocervical ligament is a true ligament of the uterus, extending from the cervix and upper vagina to the pubic symphysis. It provides support to the anterior aspect of the uterus and helps maintain its position within the pelvis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The anteversion of the uterus, which refers to the uterus tilting forward over the bladder, is mainly maintained by the uterosacral and round ligaments, not the cardinal ligaments. The cardinal ligaments, also known as the transverse cervical ligaments, primarily provide lateral support to the cervix and uterus and help in maintaining their position within the pelvis, but they are not the key ligaments for maintaining anteversion.

 

  • Structures attached to uterine cornua:
  1. Fallopian tube
  2. Round ligament is attached to the uterine cornua below and in front of the fallopian tube.
  3. Ligament of ovary is attached to the uterine cornua below and behind the fallopian tube.
  • Anteversion is maintained by:
  1. Forward pull-on uterine fundus by traction of round ligament
  2. Backward pull on the cervix by traction of the uterosacral ligaments
  3. Intrinsic growth of uterine musculature

 

 

Ref: Gray’s Anatomy 41st Edition, Pg No. 1294

choices.text: The Diagnosis is Rupture Ectopic Pregnancy.
There is Hemorrhage in the Peritoneal Cavity, especially into the Pouch of Douglas.
Irritation of Parietal Peritoneum results in Tenderness and Muscle Guarding
Collection of Pus in Pouch of Douglas can be removed through an Incision in Anterior Fornix.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female married for the past 4 months, experienced acute pain in the lower abdomen and was rushed to the hospital in a state of shock. A history of two missed periods suggested early pregnancy. The abdominal wall showed tenderness and guarding. Ultrasound revealed empty and enlarged uterus and fluid in the pouch of douglas. Which of the following statements is not true?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Collection of Pus in Pouch of Douglas can be removed through an Incision in Anterior Fornix.

 

Option D:

 

  • Collection of pus in pouch of Douglas can be removed through an incision in posterior fornix.

 

 

  • Rectouterine pouch of Douglas: Most dependent part of peritoneal cavity in female.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The clinical presentation of acute pain, shock, history of missed periods, and an ultrasound showing an empty, enlarged uterus with fluid in the pouch of Douglas strongly suggests a ruptured ectopic pregnancy. In an ectopic pregnancy, the fertilized egg implants outside the uterus, often in a fallopian tube, and if it ruptures, it can cause severe internal bleeding.

 

Option B. In the case of a ruptured ectopic pregnancy, internal bleeding can occur, leading to the accumulation of blood in the peritoneal cavity, particularly in the pouch of Douglas, which is the lowest part of the peritoneal cavity in females.

 

Option C. Irritation of the parietal peritoneum, such as from blood due to a ruptured ectopic pregnancy, can cause severe pain, tenderness, and reflexive muscle guarding in an attempt to protect the inflamed area.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • First, the described situation involves hemorrhage (blood), not pus. Pus in the pouch of Douglas typically indicates a pelvic abscess, which is a different condition. While it is true that a pelvic abscess located in the pouch of Douglas can be drained through an incision in the anterior fornix of the vagina, this is not relevant to the case described, which involves hemorrhage likely due to a ruptured ectopic pregnancy, not an abscess.
  • Boundaries:

 

 

 

  • The Vagina forms Four Fornices around the Vaginal Part of the Cervix: Anterior, Posterior and two Laterals.

 

 

Ref: Gray’s Anatomy 41st Edition, Pg No. 1295

questions.text: In the given image, which among the following structures is not attached at the pointed area?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mackenrodt's Ligament

 

Option B:

 

  • Mackenrodt’s Ligament/Transverse Cervical Ligament/Cardinal Ligament extends from cervicovaginal junction to the fascia covering levator ani.

 

 

  • Fallopian Tube is attached to the Uterine Cornua/Lateral Angle of the Uterus.
  • Round ligament is attached anteroinferiorly and Ligament of ovary is attached posteroinferiorly.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The fallopian tubes are indeed attached to the uterus. Each fallopian tube extends from the upper portion of the uterus toward the ovaries. They play a crucial role in the reproductive system, facilitating the passage of the ova (eggs) from the ovaries to the uterus.

 

Option C. Ligament of Ovary, also known as the ovarian ligament, it is a fibrous ligament that connects the ovary to the lateral surface of the uterus. This ligament is important in keeping the ovary in close relationship with the uterus.

 

Option D. The round ligament of the uterus is attached to the uterus, specifically at the uterine cornua. It extends from the uterus, passes through the inguinal canal, and terminates in the labia majora. It helps in maintaining the uterus in its anteverted position.

 

Educational objective:

 

Mackenrodt's ligament, also known as the cardinal ligament or transverse cervical ligament, is actually attached to the uterus. It extends from the side of the cervix and the vagina to the lateral pelvic wall. It is a major ligament that provides support to the uterus.

 

Ref: Gray’s Anatomy 41st Edition, Pg No. 1294

choices.text: The Fallopian receives Blood Supply from Ovarian and Uterine Arteries.
During Tubectomy, Fallopian Tube is identified by its Fimbrial End.
The Preganglionic Sympathetic Fibres to Fallopian Tube come from T6 to T9 Segments of Spinal Cord.
Lymphatics from Intramural Part of Fallopian Tube drains into Superficial Inguinal Lymph Nodes.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female who was the mother of two boys was pregnant for the third time and gave birth to a girl child in normal delivery. Following which, she gave consent for the sterilization procedure and tubectomy was done successfully. Which of the following statements is not true?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The Preganglionic Sympathetic Fibres to Fallopian Tube come from T6 to T9 Segments of Spinal Cord.

 

Option C: The preganglionic sympathetic fibres to fallopian tube come from T10 to L2 segments of spinal cord.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The fallopian tubes receive blood supply from both the ovarian artery (which arises from the abdominal aorta) and the uterine artery (which is a branch of the internal iliac artery). This dual supply ensures adequate blood flow to the fallopian tubes.

 

 

Option B. During a tubectomy, which is a procedure to cut, tie, or otherwise block the fallopian tubes (tubal ligation), the tubes are often identified by their fimbrial end. The fimbriae are the finger-like projections at the end of the fallopian tubes near the ovaries.

 

Option D. The lymphatic drainage of the fallopian tubes primarily goes to the pelvic and para-aortic lymph nodes, not the superficial inguinal lymph nodes. The intramural part of the fallopian tube, which is the portion that passes through the uterine wall, would follow this general pattern of lymphatic drainage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The sympathetic innervation of the fallopian tubes is not typically described as coming from the T6 to T9 spinal segments. Rather, the sympathetic fibers that innervate the pelvis, including the fallopian tubes, generally originate from the lower thoracic and upper lumbar segments (around T10-L2).

 

Ref: Gray’s Anatomy 41st Edition, Pg No. 1301

choices.text: Enterocele forms a Bulge at the Posterior Fornix.
Rectocele may bulge into the Lower Vagina.
Pubococcygeus Portion of Levator Ani assists Urinary Flow.
Broad Ligament is an important Uterine support to prevent Prolapse.

questions.text: A 62-year-old female from a rural area and mother to six children presented to gynec. OPD with complaints of back pain and the sensation of something “coming down” her vagina, especially when she was standing. She also complained of feeling of wetness when she coughed, sneezed, or lifted a heavy object. She also complained that her frequency to micturate has increased about fifteen times per day. Pelvic examination revealed a first degree uterine prolapse and prolapse of the bladder base. Vaginal hysterectomy and an anterior colporrhaphy were performed and the patient was subsequently relieved of her symptoms. Which of the following statements is not correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Broad Ligament is an important Uterine support to prevent Prolapse.

 

Option D: Several fascial ligaments, including the round ligament of the uterus and the rectouterine ligaments, and the cardinal ligaments help maintain the orientation of the uterus and cervix, and aid in supporting the pelvic viscera but broad ligament and other peritoneal folds exert negligible support for uterus.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. An enterocele is a type of pelvic organ prolapse where the small bowel descends into the lower pelvic cavity and creates a bulge in the posterior vaginal fornix. This condition usually occurs after a hysterectomy but can also be found in conjunction with other forms of prolapse.

 

Option B. A rectocele occurs when the front wall of the rectum bulges into the back wall of the vagina. This usually happens due to a weakening of the supportive tissues between these two structures and is often noticeable as a bulge in the lower vagina.

 

Option C. The pubococcygeus muscle is a part of the levator ani muscle group and plays a role in urinary continence. It supports the pelvic organs and assists in the control of urinary flow by maintaining the appropriate position and tension of the urethra. Urinary flow is controlled voluntarily by the striated urethrovaginal sphincter muscle. This action is assisted by the pubococcygeus portion (levator prostate in the male) of the levator ani.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The broad ligament is a double layer of peritoneum that extends from the sides of the uterus to the lateral walls of the pelvis, but it does not provide significant structural support to the uterus. The primary supports of the uterus that prevent prolapse are the pelvic floor muscles (levator ani), uterosacral ligaments, cardinal ligaments, and the round ligaments. The broad ligament mainly serves as a mesentery for the uterus, fallopian tubes, and ovaries, but it is not a key structure in preventing uterine prolapse.

 

Ref: Vishram Singh, Textbook of Anatomy, 3rd Edition, Vol. II, Abdomen, Pg. 257

choices.text: The Round Ligament of the Uterus needs to be cut to Excise the Uterus.
The Uterine Artery requires careful dissection.
Uterus is detached by cutting Below the Internal os of the Cervix.
Uterine Fibroids are Smooth Muscle Tumors of the Uterus.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female patient presented to gynaec OPD with complaints of irregular and painful menses, and an unexplained abdominal mass. The patient reports that she has four children. On physical examination, a large palpable, non-tender mass of 8 cm in diameter, in the lower abdomen. Bowel sounds are present and normal. An exploratory laparotomy was planned. The patient was advised that she may have to perform a hysterectomy if needed. For surgery, a midline incision up to the umbilicus was made, rectus muscles & fascia were retracted. Intraoperatively, it was found that the uterus was enlarged and had large fibroid tumors. Ovaries were normal in size and morphology. Hysterectomy was performed. The excised uterus weighed in at four kilograms. Which of the following statements pertaining to the above case is not true?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Uterus is detached by cutting Below the Internal os of the Cervix.

 

Option C:

 

  • Uterus is detached by cutting below the external os of the cervix and suturing the four corners of the vaginal wall.

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. During a hysterectomy, the round ligaments, which are attached to the uterus, need to be cut to remove the uterus. The round ligaments extend from the uterine cornua to the labia majora through the inguinal canal and are severed to allow for the removal of the uterus. The round ligament of the uterus, ligament of the ovary, anterior leaf of the broad ligament and the lateral attachments of the broad ligament are all cut to excise the uterus.

 

Option B. The uterine artery, which arises from the internal iliac artery and supplies blood to the uterus, must be carefully dissected and ligated during a hysterectomy to prevent excessive bleeding. The ureters pass under the uterine arteries on their way to the bladder, hence careful dissection of the uterine artery is essential to prevent injury to the ureter.

 

Option D. Uterine fibroids, also known as leiomyomas or myomas, are benign (non-cancerous) tumors made up of smooth muscle cells and fibrous connective tissue. They develop in the uterus and are a common reason for performing a hysterectomy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In a total hysterectomy, the uterus is typically detached at the level of the cervix, which includes both the internal and external os. The cervix is removed along with the uterus. In a subtotal or partial hysterectomy, the uterine body is removed while leaving the cervix in place, but this does not involve cutting below the internal os.

 

Ref: Vishram Singh, Textbook of Anatomy, 3rd Edition, Vol. II, Abdomen, Pg. 259

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with lower abdominal pain and discomfort. During a pelvic examination, the physician identifies tenderness and swelling in the lower lateral region of the vaginal wall. Which of the following structures is NOT typically related to the tenderness in this area?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Inferior Vesical Artery

 

Option C:

  • The tenderness and swelling in the lower lateral region of the vaginal wall, known as the lateral fornix, are typically related to structures in close proximity.

 

 

  • The lateral fornix is closely associated with the ureter, uterine artery, and transverse cervical ligament.
  • In this case, the inferior vesical artery, which supplies blood to the bladder and is not directly related to the lateral fornix, is the exception and is less likely to be the cause of the patient's symptoms.
  • In females, inferior vesical artery corresponds to vaginal artery which divides into several small branches and anastomose in the median line.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The ureter is related to the lateral fornix, lies 2 cm lateral to the cervix. As the ureter approaches the bladder, it runs close to the cervix and the lateral fornices of the vagina. This anatomical relationship is clinically significant because surgical procedures involving the cervix or the upper vagina can put the ureters at risk of injury.

 

 

Option B. The uterine artery is also related to the lateral fornix. The artery typically crosses above the ureter at the level of the internal os of the cervix, near the area of the lateral fornices. This relationship is described in surgical anatomy as the ureter being "water under the bridge" (the bridge being the uterine artery).

 

Option D. Uterosacral Ligament are attached to the sacral vertebrae and doesnot found in broad ligament.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The inferior vesical artery primarily supplies the bladder and is not directly related to the lateral fornix of the vagina. It branches from the internal iliac artery and primarily concerns the bladder and in males, the prostate.

 

Ref: Vishram Singh, Textbook of Anatomy, 3rd Edition, Vol. II, Abdomen, Pg. 255

questions.text: A 28-year-old female presents with severe pelvic pain and discomfort. During the physical examination, the physician notes tenderness in the lower abdomen and pelvic region. Imaging studies reveal an abnormality within the broad ligament. Which of the following structures is NOT typically found within the broad ligament?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ovary

 

Option A:

 

  • Ovary is not a content of broad ligament; it lies in ovarian fossa on the lateral pelvic wall.
  • The broad ligament is a double layer of peritoneum that extends from the lateral pelvic wall to cover and support various structures in the female pelvis.
  • It contains the round ligament, ovarian ligament, and the uterine tube.
  • However, the ovary itself is not a part of the broad ligament; it lies in the ovarian fossa on the lateral pelvic wall.
  • In cases of severe pelvic pain within the broad ligament, it is important to consider conditions involving the structures actually contained within it, such as ovarian cysts or uterine tube abnormalities.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. The round ligament of the uterus is indeed a content of the broad ligament. It runs within the broad ligament from the uterine horns to the labia majora, passing through the inguinal canal.

 

Option C. The ovarian ligament, which connects the ovaries to the uterus, is also contained within the broad ligament. It is a fibrous ligament that anchors the ovary to the lateral surface of the uterus.

 

Option D. This is also correct. The round ligament is a content of the broad ligament.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ovary is not a content of the broad ligament. The broad ligament is a fold of peritoneum that extends from the sides of the uterus to the lateral walls and floor of the pelvis. While it is associated with the ovaries, as it contains the mesovarium (the part of the broad ligament that attaches to the ovaries), the ovaries themselves are not enclosed within the broad ligament.

 

Contents of Broad Ligament:

 

  1. Uterine tube except intramural part
  2. Proximal part of round ligament
  3. Ligament of ovary
  4. Ovarian vessels
  5. Uterine vessels
  6. Tubules and ductules of epoophoron
  7. Tubules of paroophoron
  8. Lymphatics, nerves, accessory suprarenal tissue

 

Ref: Vishram Singh, Textbook of Anatomy, 3rd Edition, Vol. II, Abdomen, Pg. 262

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents with complaints of lower abdominal pain and discomfort. She describes the pain as sharp and constant, predominantly on her right side. During the physical examination, she mentions tenderness in the lower abdomen, and the physician suspects ovarian pathology. Which of the following regions is most commonly associated with referred pain in cases of ovarian pathology?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Medial Thigh

 

Option C:

 

  • Ovarian pathology, such as ovarian cysts or ovarian torsion, can lead to referred pain.
  • In cases of ovarian pathology, it is common for the patient to experience referred pain in the medial thigh.
  • This occurs due to shared neural pathways and can be explained by the embryological origin of the nerves that innervate both the ovaries and the medial thigh.
  • Therefore, when evaluating a patient with lower abdominal pain and tenderness, it's important to consider the possibility of ovarian pathology, especially if they report discomfort in the medial thigh region.

 

Explanation:

 

  • Lateral surface of Ovary rests on ovarian fossa, the floor of which is related to the obturator nerve beneath the peritoneum. Obturator nerve innervates muscles in the medial compartment of thigh and also skin over medial aspect of thigh. Hence, ovarian pathology is referred to the medial thigh.
  • Pain from ovarian pathology is typically referred to the medial thigh. This referred pain occurs due to the shared nerve supply between the ovaries and the dermatomes of the medial thigh. The ovarian and pelvic structures are primarily innervated by the T10-L1 spinal segments.
  • The obturator nerve, which innervates the medial aspect of the thigh, arises from the lumbar plexus formed by the L2-L4 nerve roots. Due to the overlap in this nerve supply, pain originating from the ovaries can be perceived in the medial thigh region.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Boundaries of Ovarian Fossa:

 

 

 

Ref: Vishram Singh, Textbook of Anatomy, 3rd Edition, Vol. II, Abdomen, Pg. 255

questions.text: A 32-year-old female presents with severe pelvic pain and discomfort on her right side. She describes the pain as sharp and radiating towards her lower abdomen. During the physical examination, the physician suspects an issue within the ovarian fossa. Which of the following structures does NOT contribute to the formation of the ovarian fossa?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Round Ligament

 

Option D:

 

  • The ovarian fossa is a shallow depression on the lateral wall of the pelvis, where the ovary is situated. Round ligament extends from the uterine angle to labia majora. It doesn’t contribute to ovarian fossa.
  • The ovarian fossa is a region in the female pelvis that houses the ovary.
  • It is formed by several structures, including the obliterated umbilical artery, the internal iliac artery, and the ureter.

 

 

  • These structures create a supportive environment for the ovary within the pelvic cavity. However, the round ligament, which connects the uterus to the labia majora and plays a role in uterine support, is not part of the formation of the ovarian fossa.
  • Therefore, in cases of severe pelvic pain within the ovarian fossa, it's important to consider issues related to the structures that actually contribute to its formation.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The obliterated umbilical artery, also known as the medial umbilical ligament forms the anterosuperior relation for ovarian fossa. It is a remnant of the fetal umbilical artery and runs from the anterior abdominal wall to the umbilicus. It is not directly related to the ovarian fossa.

 

Option B. The internal iliac artery is indeed related to the ovarian fossa. The ovarian fossa is bounded posteriorly by the internal iliac artery and its branches. The location of the fossa is just medial to where the internal iliac artery bifurcates into its anterior and posterior divisions.

 

Option C. The ureter is also related to the ovarian fossa. The fossa is located anterior to the ureter. The relationship of the ovary to the ureter is clinically significant, particularly during surgical procedures in the pelvic area. Obturator nerve lies on the lateral wall/floor of ovarian fossa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The round ligament of the uterus does not form a boundary of the ovarian fossa. The round ligament extends from the uterus, passes through the inguinal canal, and ends in the labia majora. It is not involved in the formation of the ovarian fossa.

 

Ref: Vishram Singh, Textbook of Anatomy, 3rd Edition, Vol. II, Abdomen, Pg. 255

questions.text: Lymph nodes draining the Upper Part of Vagina and Cervix are?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) External Iliac

 

Option B:

 

  • Lymphatics from the cervix and upper vagina can reach external iliac nodes, obturator nodes (laterally), internal iliac nodes (posterolaterally) and sacral nodes (posteriorly).

 

 

  • The lymphatic drainage of the upper part of the vagina and cervix is a critical aspect of gynecological anatomy, particularly in the context of the spread of cancer.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Para-aortic Lymph Nodes, located near the aorta, are indeed involved in the drainage of the cervix, particularly the upper part. They are a common site for metastasis in cases of cervical cancer. However, they are more commonly associated with the drainage of the fundus of the uterus rather than the upper part of the vagina.

 

Option C. Superficial Inguinal Lymph Nodes drain the lower extremities, the lower abdominal wall, and external genitalia including the lower part of the vagina. They are not primarily involved in the drainage of the upper part of the vagina or the cervix. Few lymphatics from the lateral angle of the uterus drain into superficial inguinal lymph nodes.

 

Option D. Deep Inguinal Lymph Nodes, located deeper in the groin under the fascia, primarily drain the lower extremities, external genitalia, and lower part of the vagina, similar to the superficial inguinal nodes. They are not the primary nodes for drainage of the cervix or upper part of the vagina.

 

 Educational Objective:

 

External Iliac Lymph Nodes are primarily responsible for the lymphatic drainage of the upper part of the vagina and the cervix. They are situated along the external iliac vessels and are a key group in the pelvic lymphatic system. In cases of cervical and upper vaginal cancers, these nodes are often evaluated for metastasis.

 

Ref: Vishram Singh, Textbook of Anatomy, 3rd Edition, Vol. II, Abdomen, Pg. 269

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents with complaints of pain and discomfort in her perineal region. She reports sharp pain during urination and difficulty controlling her urine flow. The physician suspects an issue in the superficial perineal pouch. Which of the following structures is NOT typically found within the superficial perineal pouch in females and may not contribute to the patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Sphincter Urethrae Muscle

 

Option D:

 

  • The superficial perineal pouch in females contains several structures related to the external genitalia and perineum, including the root of the clitoris, dorsal artery of the clitoris, and the perineal nerve.
  • These structures play roles in sexual function and sensory innervation of the perineal region.
  • However, the sphincter urethrae muscle, which is responsible for urinary continence, is not typically found within the superficial perineal pouch.

 

Issues related to the sphincter urethrae muscle can indeed lead to urinary symptoms but would not be directly associated with the superficial perineal pouch.

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The root of the clitoris is indeed a content of the superficial perineal pouch. It includes the crura of the clitoris and the bulbs of the vestibule, which are covered by the ischiocavernosus and bulbospongiosus muscles, respectively.

 

Option B. The dorsal artery of the clitoris, a branch of the internal pudendal artery, is also located in the superficial perineal pouch. This artery supplies blood to the clitoris.

 

Option C. The perineal nerve, a branch of the pudendal nerve, is present in the superficial perineal pouch. It provides sensory innervation to the perineal area and motor innervation to the muscles in the superficial and deep perineal pouches.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The sphincter urethrae muscle, or the external urethral sphincter, is not located in the superficial perineal pouch. It is a part of the deep perineal pouch. This muscle is responsible for voluntary control of urination.

 

 

Ref: Vishram Singh, Textbook of Anatomy, 3rd Edition, Vol. II, Abdomen, Pg. 222

choices.text: Posterior Approach to the Bladder can injure the Rectum.
Lateral Approach to the Bladder does not Damage Vascular Structures.
Suprapubic Cystostomy provides an Extraperitoneal Approach.
Apex of the Bladder gives attachment to Median Umbilical Ligament.

questions.text: A 64-year-old known case of benign prostate hypertrophy experienced difficulty in micturition. On examination the lower abdomen was distended. Ultrasound abdomen showed a distended urinary bladder. Following failure of transurethral catheterization, the surgeon decided on percutaneous cystostomy. Which of the following statements is not correct in the above scenario?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lateral Approach to the Bladder does not Damage Vascular Structures.

 

Option B:

 

  • A lateral approach to the bladder poses a risk of damaging nearby vascular structures, particularly branches of the internal iliac artery.
  • Surgeons must have a strong grasp of pelvic anatomy, use precise techniques, and employ precautions to prevent vascular injury during bladder-related procedures.
  • Patient selection, imaging guidance, and meticulous surgical care are essential for minimizing this risk.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. A posterior approach to the bladder carries a risk of damaging the rectum. The rectum is located posteriorly to the bladder, and care must be taken to avoid rectal injury during any surgical intervention in this area.

 

Option C.  A suprapubic cystostomy is performed above the pubic symphysis and allows access to the bladder without entering the peritoneal cavity, making it an extraperitoneal approach. This reduces the risk of intra-abdominal organ injury.

 

 

Option D. The apex of the bladder is connected to the umbilicus by the median umbilical ligament, which is a remnant of the urachus, a structure present during fetal development.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The lateral approach to the bladder does pose a risk to vascular structures. The internal iliac vessels and their branches, including the superior and inferior vesical arteries, are in close proximity to the bladder and can be damaged during a lateral approach. Hence, surgeons must be cautious of these vascular structures during the procedure.

 

Ref: Gray’s Anatomy 41st Edition Pg No.1255

choices.text: The Penis should be held at a 90 Degree and Catheter advanced into the External Urethral Meatus.
Maximum Resistance is encountered at the External Urethral Meatus.
The Catheter should be inserted Gently and should be kept as close as possible to the Roof of Navicular Fossa.
Membranous Urethra is the most fixed part of Male Urethra.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male was posted for total hip replacement surgery following a road traffic accident.The newly joined staff nurse was instructed to catheterize the patient before surgery. The foley’s catheter was then successfully inserted and urine started to flow into the bag. Which of the following statements regarding the above procedure is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The Catheter should be inserted Gently and should be kept as close as possible to the Roof of Navicular Fossa.

 

Option C:

 

  • The double curve of urethra is converted into a single continuous curve by elevating the penis to 90 degrees during passage of catheter.
  • The external urethral meatus is the narrowest part of male urethra, maximum resistance to the catheter will be at this point.
  • The lacuna magna in the roof of navicular fossa of glans penis is large enough to receive the tip of the catheter and may get perforated hence catheter is kept as close to the floor of navicular fossa, not the roof of navicular fossa.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. This statement is correct. When inserting a catheter in a male, the penis should be held perpendicular to the body (at a 90-degree angle) to straighten the natural S-curve of the urethra. This positioning facilitates easier insertion of the catheter.

 

Option B. This statement is generally correct. The narrowest part of the male urethra is typically the external urethral meatus, and resistance can be encountered at this point during catheterization. Care must be taken to gently navigate the catheter through this area.

 

Option D.  This statement is correct. The membranous urethra is the shortest and least dilatable part of the urethra, and it passes through the urogenital diaphragm. It is relatively fixed in position compared to the other parts of the urethra.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The navicular fossa is part of the anterior urethra. When inserting a catheter, there is no specific requirement or recommendation to keep the catheter close to the roof of the navicular fossa. The catheter should be inserted gently and smoothly without forcing it, following the natural course of the urethra.

 

Ref: Gray’s Anatomy 41st Edition Pg No: 1261

choices.text: The Diagnosis is Torsion of Left Side Testis.
Torsion will compress the Sympathetic and cause Severe Pain.
Torsion may occur in Either Clockwise or Anticlockwise Direction.
The Spermatic Cord on the Left Side is Longer than the Right.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy felt a sudden severe pain over his left scrotum. On examination in surgery OPD swelling and redness were noticed on left side of his scrotum, firm & tender left testicle higher than the right side. Scrotal ultrasound showed decreased flow on the left side, left testis hypoechoic and swollen. Which of the following statement is not true?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Torsion will compress the Sympathetic and cause Severe Pain.

 

Option B:

  • In the described scenario of a 17-year-old boy with sudden severe pain in the left scrotum, accompanied by swelling, redness, firm, and tender left testicle positioned higher than the right, and an ultrasound showing decreased blood flow.
  • Torsion of testis is due to twisting of spermatic cord, most common in prepubertal boys which can lead to decreased blood flow to the testicle resulting in ischaemia, infarction and tissue necrosis.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The clinical presentation and ultrasound findings are consistent with testicular torsion, a urological emergency where the spermatic cord twists, cutting off blood supply to the testis.

 

Option C. Testicular torsion can occur in either direction – clockwise or anticlockwise. The direction of the torsion is not predictive of the outcome and does not change the urgency or treatment approach.

 

Option D. While there can be individual variations in the length of the spermatic cord on either side, there is no established rule or tendency for the left spermatic cord to be longer than the right. Testicular torsion can occur on either side regardless of the length of the spermatic cord.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Testicular torsion causes severe pain primarily due to ischemia (lack of blood supply) and subsequent infarction of the testicular tissue, not due to compression of the sympathetic nerves. The pain is acute and severe due to the sudden loss of blood supply and resultant damage to the testicular tissue.

 

Ref: Gray’s Anatomy 41st Edition Pg No. 1272

choices.text: Stability of the Pelvic Ring is based in Large Part by Ligamentous attachments
The Internal Iliac Artery is known as the “Pelvic Artery”
Chance of Injury to Membranous or Spongy Urethra should be excluded
Internal Iliac Artery forms the Anterior Boundary of Ovarian Fossa in a Female

questions.text: A 33-year-old male presents to the E.R. after a motorcycle vs. car accident. The patient is awake and alert, and reports pain in his abdomen and pelvis. On physical examination you note that his vital signs are heart rate 120, blood pressure 120/60, respiratory rate 30. Examination also reveals abrasions on his abdominal wall surface and no signs or presence of blood on his external urethral meatus. Palpation reveals generalized tenderness over the entire abdominal region. In addition, the patient shows particular discomfort when you attempt to assess the stability of his pelvis by placing your hands over his pubic symphysis and laterally applying pressure over the iliac blades. He does not have full hip extension and rotation when you assess his mobility while lying on the exam table. Rectal exam is negative for gross blood, and the patient has a normally placed prostate. X-Rays of the pelvis in 3 planes (AP, lateral, and oblique views) was ordered to determine if the patient has a fractured pelvis and a flat plate of the abdomen to determine if the patient has free air in his abdomen. A diagnostic supraumbilical peritoneal lavage turns out negative. The patient was diagnosed with a pelvic fracture, complicated by internal bleeding. Angiography showed a laceration of the internal pudendal artery, and a selective embolization is performed. External fixation of the pelvis is performed after the bleeding has been stabilized. Which of the following statements pertaining to the above case is not true?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Internal Iliac Artery forms the Anterior Boundary of Ovarian Fossa in a Female

 

Option D:

 

  • Internal iliac artery actually forms part of the posterior boundary of the ovarian fossa, not the anterior boundary.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The stability of the pelvic ring is indeed largely dependent on its ligamentous attachments. Anteriorly, the pubic portions are joined by the pubic symphysis and posteriorly they are attached to the sacrum by strong posterior and anterior sacroiliac ligament. These ligamentous attachments themselves can be displaced.

 

Option B. The internal iliac artery, also known as the hypogastric artery, is commonly referred to as the pelvic artery. It is a major artery supplying blood to the pelvic organs, gluteal region, and perineum, it divides into anterior and posterior division to provide the blood supply to most of the pelvic structures.

 

Option C. In the setting of a pelvic fracture, particularly with reported abdominal pain and discomfort upon pelvic manipulation, it is important to consider and exclude the possibility of urethral injury. The membranous and spongy (penile) parts of the urethra are vulnerable in pelvic fractures.

 

Educational objective:

 

The ovarian fossa is a shallow depression on the lateral wall of the pelvis in females, located posterior to the internal iliac artery, not anterior. Therefore, the internal iliac artery actually forms part of the posterior boundary of the ovarian fossa, not the anterior boundary.

 

Ref: Vishram Singh Textbook of Anatomy 3rd Edition, Vol. II, Abdomen Pg 254

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with urinary symptoms such as frequent urination and difficulty initiating urination. The physician performs a per rectal examination to assess the patient's condition. During the examination, certain structures are palpated. Which of the following structures is typically NOT felt with a per rectal examination in males and may not be relevant to the patient's urinary symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ureter

 

Option C:

 

  • A per rectal examination is a digital examination performed by a healthcare provider to assess the rectal and pelvic structures in males. During this examination, the following structures can be typically palpated:
    • Anorectal ring: To assess for any anal or rectal abnormalities.
    • Prostate: To evaluate the size, consistency, and any signs of enlargement or nodules.
    • Bulb of penis: To assess for any abnormalities in the perineal area and the proximal part of the urethra.

 

 

  • However, the ureters, which are responsible for carrying urine from the kidneys to the bladder, are not typically felt during a per rectal examination.
  • Ureteral issues are usually evaluated through other diagnostic methods, such as imaging studies, and are not directly assessed through this rectal examination. In the context of the patient's urinary symptoms, the focus would be on assessing the prostate and other pelvic structures.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The anorectal ring, which is a muscular structure formed by the deep part of the external anal sphincter and the puborectalis muscle, can be felt during a per rectal examination. Surgical incision of anorectal ring produces faecal incontinence.
